levels.4: Presentation is consistently clear, logical, and well-organized.
levels.3: Presentation is mostly clear and logical with minor lapses in organization.
levels.2: Presentation is somewhat organized but lacks clarity or logical flow.
levels.1: Presentation is disorganized and difficult to follow.

levels.4: Language choices are imaginative, memorable, and enhance the effectiveness of the presentation.
levels.3: Language choices are appropriate and generally support the effectiveness of the presentation.
levels.2: Language choices are mundane and only partially support the effectiveness of the presentation.
levels.1: Language choices are unclear and minimally support the effectiveness of the presentation.

levels.4: Delivery techniques (posture, gesture, eye contact, vocal expressiveness) make the presentation compelling.
levels.3: Delivery techniques make the presentation interesting, though not compelling.
levels.2: Delivery techniques make the presentation understandable, but not interesting.
levels.1: Delivery techniques detract from the understandability of the presentation.

levels.4: A variety of types of supporting materials make appropriate reference to information or analysis that significantly supports the presentation.
levels.3: Supporting materials make appropriate reference to information or analysis that generally supports the presentation.
levels.2: Supporting materials make appropriate reference to information or analysis that partially supports the presentation.
levels.1: Insufficient supporting materials are used or supporting materials do not support the presentation.

levels.4: Central message is compelling, precisely stated, appropriately repeated, and strongly supported.
levels.3: Central message is clear and consistent with the supporting material.
levels.2: Central message is basically understandable but is not often repeated and is not memorable.
levels.1: Central message can be deduced, but is not explicitly stated in the presentation.
